homepage = {{URL|www.trex.com}} | footnotes = | intl = }} '''Trex Company, Inc.''' known to global consumers and others simply as Trex or Trex Decking, is the leading recycled materials manufacturer of [[Wood-plastic composite|wood-alternative decking]], railings and other outdoor items.{{cite web|last1=Harrison|first1=J.D.|title=Not-real-wood company Trex posts a very real earnings bump|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/on-small-business/not-real-wood-company-trex-posts-a-very-real-earnings-bump/2014/08/04/a3592382-1c01-11e4-ab7b-696c295ddfd1_story.html|website=www.washingtonpost.com|publisher=Washington Post|accessdate=26 March 2015}} It has been a public company since 1999 and trades on the New York Stock Exchange under the ticker symbol “TREX”. The company was founded in 1996 and is headquartered in [[Winchester, Virginia|Winchester]], [[Virginia|VA]], USA.{{cite web|title=Trex Company, Inc. Stock Quowte & Summary Data|url=http://www.nasdaq.com/symbol/trex|publisher=NASDAQ|accessdate=31 August 2013}} With manufacturing facilities in Fernley, Nevada and Winchester, Virginia, the company’s products are sold in 29 countries. Trex products are carried by approximately 6,700 retail locations worldwide.{{cite web|title=Trex Investor Presentation - November 2015|url=http://investor.trex.com/phoenix.zhtml?c=86979&p=irol-presentations|publisher=Trex Company, Inc.|accessdate=28 January 2016}} According to public documents, the company is the world’s largest [[Manufacturing|manufacturer]] of [[Wood-plastic composite|wood-alternative decking]] and [[Deck railing|railing]],{{cite web|title = The Inventor of Composite Decking|url = http://www.wctdistributors.com/who-is-trex-decking-wood-and-plastic-composite-decking-perth-western-australia/|publisher = WCTDistributors|accessdate = 31 August 2013}} with approximate 2017 annual revenues reported of $565 million{{Cite news|url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/trex-trex-q4-earnings-sales-143802999.html|title=Trex (TREX) Q4 Earnings & Sales Top, Up Y/Y on Strong Demand|access-date=2018-04-16|language=en-US}}, annual operating income of $95.1 million and net income of $326.2 million{{Cite news|url=https://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20180221006176/en/Trex-Company-Reports-Fourth-Quarter-Full-Year|title=Trex Company Reports Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2017 Results|access-date=2018-04-16|language=en}}. James E. Cline was named president and CEO of Trex effective August 17, 2015. Bryan H. Fairbanks was named vice president and CFO effective August 17, 2015. Key executives of Trex Decking include; James E. Cline, president and chief executive officer; Bryan H. Fairbanks, vice president and chief financial officer; Ron Kaplan, chairman; Jay Scripter, vice president of operations, Chris Gerhard, vice president of sales; Adam Zambanini, vice president of marketing; Bill Gupp, chief administrative officer, general counsel and secretary.{{cite web|title=Trex Investor Presentation, June 2013|url=http://investor.trex.com/phoenix.zhtml?c=86979&p=irol-presentations|publisher=Trex Company, Inc.|accessdate=31 August 2013}}{{cite web|title=Trex Names James E. Cline President and CEO Effective August 17, 2015|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20150508005068/en/Trex-Names-James-E.-Cline-President-CEO, https://finance.yahoo.com/q/is?s=TREX&annual|website=Business Wire|accessdate=8 April 2016}}{{cite web|title=Trex Company Announces Record Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Results|url=http://www.businesswire.com/news/home/20160223005357/en/Trex-Company-Announces-Record-Fourth-Quarter-Full|website=Business Wire|accessdate=8 April 2016}}{{cite web|title=Leadership|url=http://www.trex.com/our-company/corporate-governance/|website=Trex Company, Inc|accessdate=8 April 2016}} ==Trex Composite Decking== [[File:Trex Transcend Decking and Railing stairs.png|thumb|right|Trex Composite Decking]] Trex is widely considered as one of the inventors of [[Composite lumber|composite decking]] made from recyclable materials.{{cite web|title=Product of the Month: Composite Decking|url=http://www.naturalelementhomes.com/Newsletter/natural-element-homes-newsletter-aug2012-composite-decking.html|publisher=Natural Element Houses|accessdate=18 September 2013}} The idea for a process and product created to maximize the use of materials that would otherwise wind up in [[landfill]]s is credited to inventors Kjell-Ake Gustafsson, of Binghamton, NY; John J. Muller, of Winchester, VA; and Roger A. Wittenberg of Newton, PA.{{cite web|title=Method of producing a wood-thermoplastic composite material|url=http://patft.uspto.gov/netacgi/nph-Parser?Sect1=PTO2&Sect2=HITOFF&p=1&u=%2Fnetahtml%2FPTO%2Fsearch-bool.html&r=25&f=G&l=50&co1=AND&d=PTXT&s1=5746958&OS=5746958&RS=5746958|work=United States Patent|publisher=USPTO Patent Full-Text and Image Database}} ===Company Patent=== The first patent for a “Method of Producing a Wood-Thermoplastic Composite Material” was filed as [[United States patent law|U.S. Patent]] number 5746958 in March 1995 and granted in May 1998. The Assignee was Trex Company LLC, operating in Winchester, VA. The process abstract for the creation of composite decking is: “A method for producing a wood-thermoplastic composite material using a high bulk density feedstock. Since the feedstock is easy to handle it provides manufacturers with lots of control over the process. Prompted by the prospect of environmental regulations mandating recycled materials, this process uses spent sawdust and plastic material rather than disposing of it.” ===Manufacturing Processes=== Trex continues to employ a process that combines different materials, mostly wood and plastic, that are formed to create a product that has the appearance of wood. The wood content in Trex products is largely wood byproducts like sawdust, wood pallets, wood chips and wood fiber. The polyethylene plastic continues to be mostly recycled materials from commonly discarded items like stretch wrap, packaging films, grocery and retail bags and case/carton/product overwraps.{{cite web|last=Winter|first=Richard|title=How Composite Decking Works|url=http://home.howstuffworks.com/home-improvement/construction/green/composite-decking.htm|work=How Stuff Works|publisher=HowStuffWorks, Inc.|accessdate=18 September 2013}} Trex uses about 100,000 tons of waste [[polyethylene]] film each year and claims to keep 200,000 tons of plastic and hardwood scraps out of American landfills each year.{{cite web|title=Coastal Zone Management: Trex Plastic Recycled Lumber, Virginia Marine Debris Summit 2013|url=http://www.deq.virginia.gov/Portals/0/DEQ/CoastalZoneManagement/Trex_Plastic_Recycled_Lumber_Virginia_Marine_Debris_Summit_%202013.pdf|publisher=Coastal Zone Management|accessdate=18 September 2013}} Over 120,000 pieces of post consumer film (packaging, bags, overwraps, etc.) can be used to create a 500-square-foot Trex deck.{{cite web|title=Recyclopedia: Plastic Shopping Bags|url=http://www.2good2waste.com/oceancountynj/?content=recyclopedia.view&recyclopedia_id=3329|work=2Good2Waste|publisher=IWasteNot Systems, Inc.|accessdate=18 September 2013}} The components are mixed and a pigment and preservative are added during the process. The mixture is then heated, formed into a board shape, and cooled.{{cite web|last=Winter|first=Richard|title=How Composite Decking Works|url=http://home.howstuffworks.com/home-improvement/construction/green/composite-decking.htm|work=How Stuff Works|publisher=HowStuffWorks, Inc.|accessdate=18 September 2013}} ===Transcend Decking=== In 2009 Trex introduced a ‘Transcend’ line of decking {{cite news|last=DeGroot|first=Paul|title=Synthetic Decking Roundup|url=http://www.deckmagazine.com/composite-materials/synthetic-decking-roundup.aspx|accessdate=18 September 2013|newspaper=Professional Deck Builder|date=January 1, 2012}} that is a [[Plastics extrusion|co-extruded]] composite decking product that includes a shell around the composite boards on three sides to protect the boards from staining, fading and scratching.{{cite news|last=Feingold|first=Jean|title=Latest decking trends for remodelers|url=http://www.housingzone.com/deckingoutdoor-living/latest-decking-trends-remodelers|accessdate=18 September 2013|newspaper=Housing Zone|date=April 1, 2012}} The Trex Transcend line of decking claims a recycled content rate of 95.4%.{{cite news|title=Trex® Sweeps Composite Decking Category In Remodeling Magazine's 2013 Brand Use Study|url=http://www.marketwatch.com/story/trex-sweeps-composite-decking-category-in-remodeling-magazines-2013-brand-use-study-2013-07-10|accessdate=18 September 2013|newspaper=Market Watch|date=July 10, 2013}} ==Products== [[File:Trex Transcend Colonial Spindles Porch.png|thumb|right|Transcend® Porch Flooring and Railing System]] Trex products include:{{cite web|title=Trex|url=http://www.trex.com|publisher=Trex Company, Inc.|accessdate=3 September 2013}} * Elevations® Steel Deck Framing * Trex® Rain Escape® Deck Drainage System * Transcend® Decking and Railing * Enhance® Decking * Select® Decking and Railing * Transcend® Porch Flooring and Railing System * Trex® Outdoor Furniture™ * Trex® Outdoor Lighting™ * Trex® Outdoor Storage™ * Trex® Pergola™ * Trex® Spiral Stairs™ * TrexTrim™ * Trex® Seclusions® Fencing ==Environmental Record== Trex promotes an environmental stance as part of its commercial appeal in the marketplace.{{cite web|last=Roach|first=John|title=Are Plastic Grocery Bags Sacking the Environment?|url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2003/09/0902_030902_plasticbags.html|work=National Geographic News|publisher=National Geographic|accessdate=14 October 2013|date=September 2, 2003}} In public materials, Trex Company, Inc. cites that no trees are cut down to make Trex decking products; that the company uses vegetable-based oil hydraulics in transportation trailers; and that it recycles factory waste back into the manufacturing line. ===Recycled Components=== Trex composite decking contains 97% recycled content and offers verification by ICC-ES.{{cite web|title=Trex Composite Wood Products Obtain Sustainable Attributes Verification Report from ICC-ES|url=http://thegreendestination.com/resources/10-03554_Trex_FINAL_lores.pdf|work=ES-ICC Evaluation Service|publisher=The Green Destination|accessdate=19 September 2013}} In July 2010 Trex received a Verification of Attributes Report (VAR-1011) from the International Code Council Evaluation Service (ICC-ES) under the Sustainable Attributes Verification and Evaluation Program. The verification validates Trex’s wood-alternative products are manufactured with a minimum of 95.4% recycled content. Trex claims is the first composite decking manufacturer to obtain this certification.{{cite web|title=Trex Composite Wood Products Obtain Sustainable Attributes Verification Report from ICC-ES|url=http://thegreendestination.com/resources/10-03554_Trex_FINAL_lores.pdf|work=ES-ICC Evaluation Service|publisher=The Green Destination|accessdate=19 September 2013}} ====Environmental Affiliations==== Trex has been a member of the [[Green Building Council]], a trade group promoting environmentally friendly building practices, (USGBC) since 2009. USGBC is best known for the widely recognized [[Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design|LEED]] program (Leadership in Energy & Environmental Design).{{cite web|title=Trex Company|url=http://www.usgbc.org/leed|work=LEED|publisher=U.S. Green Building Council|accessdate=19 September 2013}} Through the LEED point-based system, the use of Trex decking and railing products add points based on the percentage of recycled product content. ====Environmental Programs==== Trex conducts and participates in eco-friendly educational and recycling programs in various parts of the United States.{{cite web|last=Roach|first=John|title=Are Plastic Grocery Bags Sacking the Environment?|url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2003/09/0902_030902_plasticbags.html|work=National Geographic News|publisher=National Geographic|accessdate=14 October 2013|date=September 2, 2003}} Since 2006, students at selected schools throughout the East Coast and Midwest have participated in a ‘Trex Plastic Bag Challenge’ (recently renamed ‘Plastic Film Recycling Challenge’ ). Students collect plastic bags in exchange for a gift of Trex benches to participating schools.{{cite web|title=How "Green" Outdoor Living Should Feel|url=http://www.quinnsconstruction.com/images/pdf/Trex-Green.pdf|publisher=Quinns Construction|accessdate=19 September 2013}} The company has also provided in-kind contributions, financial assistance and expertise to environmental projects around the country. These include: * The [[Creative Energy Homes#The BASF House|BASF Near Zero Energy Home]] in Paterson, NJ.{{cite web|title=Trex Company|url=http://construction.basf.us/index.php?page=residential_proof_bhbp_newConstruction_nzeh_contributors&select=34|publisher=BASF Construction|accessdate=19 September 2013}} * The Maui Wildlife Refuge Complex, Kealia Pond NWR in Hawaii. The '''voluntary social year''' in [[Austria]]<ref>http://www.fsj.at/</ref> and [[Germany]]<ref>http://www.pro-fsj.de/</ref> (German ''Freiwilliges Soziales Jahr'', abbr. FSJ) is a state-funded [[volunteering|voluntary]] work program particularly for young adults. It can last between six and eighteen months and also be spent working abroad.
The idea behind this voluntary social year has its origin in the Protestant and Roman Catholic church by organizing a diaconical year. In 1964 the German parliament conducted a law, that became the basis of the platform, that supplies officially certified organizations and government institutions with volunteers.
Possible locations are numerous and are all social, charitable or of public utility.
* Services for disabled people * Hospitals * Nursing homes * Foster homes * Preservation of historic monuments * Ambulatory services * Youth welfare services * Church communities * Emergency medical services * Children homes * Old people´s homes
Due to the existing [[conscription]] for [[military service]] in Austria, since 2016 the voluntary social year is an alternative service to the compulsory service in the [[Austrian Armed Forces]] for males.<ref>http://www.volkshilfe-wien.at/</ref><ref>http://www.sozialesjahr.at/wp-content/uploads/2014/05/zivildienst-information.pdf</ref> Before conscription was abandoned in Germany in 2011, the FSJ could be used as an alternative service for males as well.
